Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: An Ethnography of Privacy Engineering in U.S. Web Browser Development

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
A broad array of recent developments in technology, business, government, and popular culture have transformed digital surveillance into an inescapable fact of everyday life. This has contributed to the widespread perception that privacy may no longer be capable of fulfilling its traditional role in American politics: preserving and promoting individual liberty, dignity, and self-expression. In response, government, academic, civil society, and private sector institutions have launched an unprecedented number of technology-based projects designed to protect privacy for future generations. In this context, understanding the conditions under which technological design and engineering can meaningfully contribute to privacy protections is critical for developing programs and policies that can unlock the economic, scientific, and societal potential of new data technologies while still guaranteeing Americans' access to privacy's personal, political, and cultural benefits. Findings from this project, which trains a graduate student in methods of empirical, scientific data collection and analysis, will be disseminated to organizations that manage and develop policy related to privacy.

Lake Polan, under the guidance of anthropologist Dr. Joseph P. Masco of the University of Chicago, will investigate the efforts of Silicon Valley-based technology corporations to preserve privacy on the Internet using design and engineering. The project will be carried out through twelve months of research, including eleven months of ethnographic fieldwork in the San Francisco headquarters of Mozilla and one month of interviewing technologists, regulators, and other stakeholders in Washington, D.C. Mozilla is a well-known not-for-profit technology corporation, which develops Firefox, the third most popular web browser in the U.S. As a matter of official corporate policy, Mozilla is committed to protecting the privacy of users of Firefox and of the Internet in general. Through long-term, first person observation, the project will explore Mozilla's efforts to honor this principle by engineering privacy directly "into" the features and properties of its web browsing software. Mozilla's self-identified role as a leader in the industry-wide effort to enhance Internet privacy protections will enable project researchers to make a legally and socially significant assessment of the technological basis of privacy today, thus facilitating timely interventions in ongoing public policy debates about privacy, personal information, technology, and surveillance.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research for this project consisted primarily of participant observation and semi-structured interviewing of several communities in the San Francisco Bay Area working to preserve meaningful forms of privacy. The co-PI for this project spent more than 12 months in San Francisco in 2016 and 2017 observing privacy and security engineers, user experience designers, and project managers at a major web browser developer as they attempted to introduce privacy-preserving features into the Firefox web browser. The co-PI supplemented this with (i) participant observation of an Oakland citizens-activist group advocating for new surveillance technology transparency and accountability laws, and (ii) widespread interviewing of software engineers, hackers, lawyers and advocates working at the intersection of privacy and technology in Silicon Valley and Washington, D.C. The co-PI is now using the research as the empirical basis for a dissertation and journal articles concerning how the meaning, nature, and political potential of privacy appear to be changing as it increasingly comes to be understood as something that must be achieved through information technology. 

The resulting dissertation will explore the technical, design, and business challenges that browser developers face in attempting to provide users with privacy. The dissertation will describe the tendency among browser developers to define privacy in this context in terms of a user’s ability to control whether and how their browsing behavior can be tracked, analyzed, and shared with other organizations. It will explore the ways that engineers seek to implement such control in browsers, and how they attempt to balance the technical aspects of such work with the surprisingly complicated task of educating users about online privacy and security, the basic need to gather user data in order to produce a browser that can keep up with rapidly changing technical and market requirements, and their individual and corporate commitments to preserving privacy. One preliminary outcome of the research was the observation that, as privacy becomes the object of technology projects, it is becoming grounded in and defined by the varying temporalities of open source software engineering, software development project management, and of the venture capital-backed startup business cycle.  

The dissertation will further explore how technological practices are reshaping privacy in relation to broader shifts in the relationship between technology and law in contemporary American politics and culture. The dissertation will describe how the tools and techniques of privacy engineering evolved out of and continue to draw upon and feed developments, including the professionalization and standardization of privacy expertise among both lawyers and software engineers, and the ongoing, post-Snowden reevaluation by engineers, computer scientists, and technology executives of the proper role of “political” considerations in technical practices and businesses. The dissertation will explore another preliminary outcome of the project—the observation that societal responsibility for privacy appears to be shifting from lawyers and the law to engineers and technology—by detailing how software engineers manage the tension they experience between their political and ethical commitments as US citizens and their professional obligations as technologists and corporate employees. 

Finally, the dissertation will explore the ways in which privacy is becoming linked not just to the engineering and business practices through which web technologies are developed and brought to market, but also to highly localized histories of police-community relations and concerns with the spread of counter-terror logic and technology. The dissertation will pursue this through a description and analysis of the efforts of citizen activists in the Bay Area to enact municipal surveillance technology reform. Oakland Privacy, the activist group observed for this project, originated in the Occupy Oakland movement, against the backdrop of decades of attempts to establish greater citizen oversight over police forces in Oakland and Berkeley, widely viewed to be corrupt and racially biased. Oakland Privacy has become a national pioneer in enacting local reforms designed to enhance the ability of citizens to weigh in on whether and how military-grade surveillance technologies are used by local police. The co-PI observed during the research period that while Oakland Privacy seeks to defend privacy through activism and policymaking—not engineering—they share certain concepts, models, aesthetics, and techniques with privacy engineers. The dissertation will explore the changing nature of privacy in America by describing and drawing out the similarities and contrasts between the efforts of these activists and web engineers to defend privacy.
